bibl.title: Letter from Leonard Wood to John Dalzell, December 31, 1902

div1.p: Wood lobbies for a pension for Lazear's widow.

div1.head: Letter from Leonard Wood to John Dalzell, December 31, 1902
div1.opener:
Headquarters
MILITARY GOVERNOR
Island of Cuba
Havana
December 31, 1901.
COPY.
Hon. John Dlazell.
Member of Congress. Washington D. C.
My dear Mr. Dlazell:-
div1.p:
I have just received a letter from Mrs. Lazear whose
husband died from yellow fever acquired while engaged as a member of the
yellow fever commission investigating the cause of the transmission of
yellow fever.

This officer's work was of the greatest value and he sacrificed his
life in the pursuit of this investigation. It is needless to say that the
result of the work of this commission is one of incalculable value to
humanity and especially to the people of the Southern States. I believe
the result of their work will render it possible for us to control yellow
fever in the future which means the saving of millions of dollars per
rear and enormous number of lives.

I feel that the widow of Dr. Lazear is fully entitled to a pension
and that this services entitle him to this mark of consideration from his
countrymen. I doubt if any men have been engaged in recent years on any
work more important and obtained more valuable results than the members
of this commission and it is only right and just that the family of the
member of the commission who lost his life should receive every considerat
ion granted by the pension laws.
I most strongly commend this case to your favorable consideration.
